title: psychinterpreter: Getting Started
text: document demonstrates functionality psychinterpreter package using Big Five personality data psych package. Big Five Inventory (BFI) widely-used personality assessment measures five major dimensions personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism. ’ll test major features psychinterpreter including: Basic factor analysis interpretation Persistent chat sessions efficient LLM usage Export functionality across multiple formats Advanced interpretation features

title: psychinterpreter: Getting Started
code: packages <- c(   "psychinterpreter",   "ellmer",   "psych",   "lavaan",   "mirt",   "dplyr",   "here",   "pander" ) # Load required packages using pacman if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") Loading required package: pacman pacman::p_load(char = packages)  # Load the BFI dataset and dictionary data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")

title: psychinterpreter: Getting Started
text: Exclude demographic variables factor analysis Show first rows BFI data: Display BFI dictionary showing item descriptions:
code: bfi <- bfi[,1:25] bfi.dictionary <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi,10) bfi.dictionary |> select(Item) |> as.data.frame()

code: # Parallel analysis to determine optimal number of factors pa_result <- fa.parallel(   bfi,   fa = "fa",   n.iter = 100,   use = "pairwise.complete.obs",   main = "Parallel Analysis: BFI Data" ) Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  6  and the number of components =  NA fa_result <- fa(   bfi,   nfactors = pa_result$nfact,   rotate = "oblimin",   fm = "ml" ) summary(fa_result) Factor analysis with Call: fa(r = bfi, nfactors = pa_result$nfact, rotate = "oblimin", fm = "ml")  Test of the hypothesis that 6 factors are sufficient. The degrees of freedom for the model is 165  and the objective function was  0.36 The number of observations was  2800  with Chi Square =  1013.79  with prob <  4.6e-122  The root mean square of the residuals (RMSA) is  0.02 The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.03  Tucker Lewis Index of factoring reliability =  0.922 RMSEA index =  0.043  and the 90 % confidence intervals are  0.04 0.045 BIC =  -295.88  With factor correlations of       ML2   ML1   ML3   ML5   ML4   ML6 ML2  1.00  0.25 -0.18 -0.10  0.02  0.18 ML1  0.25  1.00 -0.22 -0.31 -0.19 -0.06 ML3 -0.18 -0.22  1.00  0.19  0.19 -0.03 ML5 -0.10 -0.31  0.19  1.00  0.25  0.14 ML4  0.02 -0.19  0.19  0.25  1.00  0.02 ML6  0.18 -0.06 -0.03  0.14  0.02  1.00 # Extract loading matrix for interpretation loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> as.data.frame() round(loadings_matrix, 2) # Extract factor correlation matrix factor_cor_mat <- fa_result$Phi |> as.data.frame() round(factor_cor_mat, 2) chat <- chat_fa(   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   # set temperature and seed for reproducibility   params = params(temperature = 0, seed = 42) )  print(chat) Factor Analysis Chat Session Provider: "ollama" Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" Created: 2025-11-02 17:16:05.690051 Interpretations run: 0 variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),   description = bfi.dictionary$Item,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) result <- interpret_fa(     loadings = loadings_matrix,   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   n_emergency = 2,   additional_info = NULL,   factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat,   sort_loadings = TRUE,   word_limit = 100,   max_line_length = 80,   silent = FALSE,   echo = "none",   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 2,   suppress_heading = TRUE,   chat_session = chat ) ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ℹ Processing all 6 factors... Warning: LLM interpretation for ML1 exceeded word limit ! Expected: 100 words, Got: 102 words ℹ Consider using a more restrictive model or adjusting the prompt ✔ Factor interpretation complete print(chat) Factor Analysis Chat Session Provider: "ollama" Model: "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" Created: 2025-11-02 17:16:05.690051 Interpretations run: 1 Total tokens - Input: 2008, Output: 6700 plot(result,      cutoff = 0.3) # TXT export export_interpretation(result,                       format = "txt",                       file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis")) # MD export export_interpretation(result,                       format = "md",                       file = here("exports", "bfi_analysis")) interpret(   fa_result,   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   chat_session = chat,   word_limit = 100,   heading_level = 3,   suppress_heading = TRUE,   output_format = "markdown" ) ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ℹ Processing all 6 factors... Warning: LLM interpretation for ML1 exceeded word limit ! Expected: 100 words, Got: 102 words ℹ Consider using a more restrictive model or adjusting the prompt ✔ Factor interpretation complete # Specify a CFA model for BFI data fa_lavaan <- lavaan::efa(bfi, nfactors = pa_result$nfact, rotation = "oblimin") # interpret lavaan model interpret(   fa_lavaan,   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   chat_session = chat,   word_limit = 100,   heading_level = 3,   suppress_heading = TRUE,   output_format = "markdown" ) ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ℹ Processing all 6 factors... ✔ Factor interpretation complete # specify and fit a CFA model cfa_model <- "   O =~ O1 + O2 + O3 + O4 + O5   C =~ C1 + C2 + C3 + C4 + C5   E =~ E1 + E2 + E3 + E4 + E5   A =~ A1 + A2 + A3 + A4 + A5   N =~ N1 + N2 + N3 + N4 + N5   " cfa_fit <- lavaan::cfa(cfa_model, data = bfi, std.lv = TRUE)  # interpret lavaan cfa model interpret(   cfa_fit,   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   chat_session = chat,   word_limit = 100,   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 3,   suppress_heading = TRUE ) ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ℹ Processing all 5 factors... ✔ Factor interpretation complete # Fit a unidimensional IRT model irt_model <- mirt::mirt(   data = bfi,   model =  pa_result$nfact,   itemtype = "graded",   method = "MHRM" ) # interpret mirt model interpret(   irt_model,   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.3,   chat_session = chat,   word_limit = 100,   heading_level = 3,   suppress_heading = TRUE,   output_format = "markdown" ) ℹ The description column is a factor - converting to character ℹ Using existing chat session: Ollama "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ℹ Processing all 6 factors... ✔ Factor interpretation complete

title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: psychinterpreter R package automates interpretation exploratory factor analysis (EFA) cluster analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs) via ellmer package. interfaces various LLM providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, Ollama, Gemini, Azure) generate human-readable factor names interpretations based loading patterns variable descriptions.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses sophisticated multi-stage pipeline: Analyzes factor loadings configurable cutoffs Identifies significant loadings per factor Applies “emergency rule” weak factors (uses top N variables none exceed cutoff) Detects cross-loadings orphaned variables Constructs structured prompts psychometric context Uses compact vector format efficient token usage Processes factors single LLM call (batch processing optimization) Includes factor correlations oblique rotations Supports persistent chat sessions via chat_fa objects avoid resending system prompts Builds comprehensive reports text markdown format Includes factor interpretations, cross-loadings, diagnostic information Configurable heading levels document integration Text wrapping console output

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Key innovation cost/efficiency optimization: chat_fa objects (R/chat_fa.R): Reusable LLM sessions preserve system prompt Single analysis: Creates temporary session Multiple analyses: Create one chat_fa, pass multiple interpret_fa() calls Saves ~500+ tokens per additional analysis resending system prompt

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Single Responsibility: R file handles one aspect: - interpret_fa.R: Main interpretation logic LLM coordination - chat_fa.R: Chat session management - fa_utilities.R: Data analysis utilities (cross-loadings, -loadings detection) - utils.R: Text processing helpers (word counting, text wrapping) - fa_report_functions.R: Report building formatting - export_functions.R: Multi-format export (CSV, JSON, RDS, TXT) - visualization.R: S3 plot method ggplot2-based heatmap visualizations S3 Methods: Package implements custom methods standard R generics: - print.fa_interpretation(): Formatted console output text wrapping - print.chat_fa(): Session info token usage display - plot.fa_interpretation(): Factor loading heatmap visualization - Backward-compatible wrappers: create_factor_plot() calls plot() method Provider Abstraction: Uses ellmer package’s unified interface LLM providers. Switch providers changing parameters, code. Structured Output: LLM returns JSON factor names keys, parsed fallback extraction methods robustness.

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Generate documentation from roxygen2 comments roxygen2::roxygenise()  # Run R CMD check devtools::check()  # Install package locally devtools::install()  # Load for development devtools::load_all()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: API keys must set environment variables using package: Provider-specific chat initialization handled ellmer package switch statement interpret_fa.R:587-766.
code: # OpenAI Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-key")  # Anthropic Sys.setenv(ANTHROPIC_API_KEY = "your-key")  # For Ollama (local), no key needed

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Multi-tiered fallback approach robust LLM response handling: 1. Try parsing cleaned JSON (remove extra text, fix formatting issues) 2. Fall back original response 3. Pattern-based extraction JSON parsing fails 4. Default values methods fail Critical handling small/local models may produce imperfect JSON.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package targets 80-100% word_limit parameter interpretations: - System prompt includes explicit word targets - Post-processing validates warns exceeded - Helper function count_words() utils.R

title: CLAUDE.md
text: factor_cor_mat provided (oblique rotations): - Included LLM prompt relationship context - Helps LLM understand discriminant vs. convergent validity - Displayed report sections (summary per-factor)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: factor zero loadings cutoff: - Uses top n_emergency highest absolute loadings instead - Clearly marked output WARNING - Prevents empty factor interpretations

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Roxygen2 documentation: Required exported functions Examples limit: Maximum 2 examples per function documentation Explicit namespacing: Use package::function() notation (e.g., dplyr::mutate()) CLI messaging: Use cli package user-facing messages (cli_alert_info, cli_abort, cli_warn) Pipe operator: Uses base R |> pipe (magrittr %>%) Parameter validation: Extensive validation informative error messages function start

title: CLAUDE.md
text: ellmer: LLM communication layer dplyr, tidyr: Data manipulation cli: User messaging jsonlite: JSON parsing

title: CLAUDE.md
text: ggplot2: Visualization (plot() method create_factor_plot()) testthat: Testing framework

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package exports 12 functions plus 3 S3 methods: Main Functions: - interpret_fa() - Core factor interpretation LLM - chat_fa() - Create persistent chat session - .chat_fa() - Check object chat_fa - reset.chat_fa() - Reset chat session Utilities: - find_cross_loadings() - Detect cross-loading variables - find_no_loadings() - Detect variables significant loadings - export_interpretation() - Export results multiple formats - create_factor_plot() - Standalone plotting function (wrapper) S3 Methods: - print.fa_interpretation() - Print interpretation results - print.chat_fa() - Print chat session info - plot.fa_interpretation() - Visualize factor loadings

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Currently tests implemented (tests/ directory doesn’t exist). adding tests: - Use testthat framework (already DESCRIPTION Suggests) - Skip tests requiring API keys unless credentials available - Create fixtures factor loading matrices variable descriptions - Test single-analysis persistent chat session workflows

title: CLAUDE.md
code: R/ ├── interpret_fa.R          # Main interpretation function (~1270 lines) ├── chat_fa.R               # Persistent chat session management ├── fa_utilities.R          # Cross-loading & no-loading detection ├── utils.R                 # Word counting, text wrapping ├── fa_report_functions.R   # Report building, print methods ├── export_functions.R      # Export to CSV/JSON/RDS/TXT └── visualization.R         # ggplot2 heatmap creation  dev/ └── PACKAGE_MIGRATION_PLAN.md  # Historical migration documentation  vignettes/ └── articles/     └── 01-Basic_Usage.qmd   # Example usage with BFI dataset

code: # Get interpretation results results <- interpret_fa(loadings, variable_info, silent = TRUE)  # Use S3 plot method (recommended) plot(results)  # Or use backward-compatible function create_factor_plot(results)  # Save plot p <- plot(results) ggsave("loadings.png", p, width = 10, height = 8)  # Customize plot plot(results) +   ggplot2::labs(title = "Custom Title") +   ggplot2::theme(axis.text.y = ggplot2::element_text(size = 6))

text: previously documented issues resolved: ✓ Token tracking: Fixed local input token usage tracking providers cached system prompts ✓ Parameter conflicts: Added informative message chat_session overrides llm_provider/llm_model arguments Fixed literal “n” appearing instead newlines reports (e.g., “5 nVariance” → “5”) Fixed leading zero inconsistency negative numbers (e.g., “-0.18” → “-.18” match “.45” format) ✓ Test infrastructure: Added comprehensive test suite tests/testthat/ directory ✓ Export functions: Simplified support .txt .md formats smart extension handling

what: Update 2: S3 Methods and API Refinements
title: CLAUDE.md
text: New Features: - ✓ S3 method system: Created interpret() generic methods common FA packages (R/interpret_methods.R) - interpret.psych.fa() - Handles psych::fa() results - interpret.psych.principal() - Handles psych::principal() results - interpret.lavaan() - Handles lavaan::cfa()/sem() results - interpret.efaList() - Handles lavaan::efa() results - interpret.SingleGroupClass() - Handles mirt::mirt() results - methods auto-extract loadings factor correlations model objects API Changes: - ✓ Reordered interpret_fa() arguments: logical parameter order frequently-used args first - loadings, variable_info, factor_cor_mat, chat_session, llm_provider, llm_model, params, cutoff, n_emergency, sort_loadings, additional_info, word_limit, output_format, heading_level, suppress_heading, max_line_length, silent, echo - ✓ Removed suppress_small parameter: Delegated downstream formatting functions cleaner separation concerns Utility Functions: - ✓ Optional factor_cols parameter: find_cross_loadings() find_no_loadings() now auto-detect factor columns provided - ✓ Added silent parameter export_interpretation(): Suppresses success messages testing Dependencies: - ✓ Updated DESCRIPTION: Added psych, lavaan, mirt Suggests S3 method support

what: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: LLM-powered interpretation factor cluster analyses. Disclaimer: package early development used caution. Always review validate LLM-generated interpretations.

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: 🤖 LLM-Powered Interpretation: Generate human-readable factor names interpretations using state---art language models via ‘ellmer’ package psych::fa() psych::principal() results lavaan::cfa(), lavaan::sem(), lavaan::efa() results mirt::mirt() multidimensional IRT results Auto-extracts loadings factor correlations 📊 Comprehensive Reports: Automatically generate detailed reports text markdown format 📈 Visualizations: Create publication-ready heatmaps factor loadings suggested factor names 💾 Multi-Format Export: Export results TXT MD formats 🎯 Provider Agnostic: Works OpenAI, Anthropic, Google Gemini, Azure, Ollama, via ‘ellmer’ 🔄 Persistent Chat Sessions: Reuse LLM sessions across multiple analyses save tokens reduce costs

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: can install development version psychinterpreter GitHub:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("https://github.com/matthiaskloft/psychinterpreter")

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych)  # Run factor analysis fa_result <- fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # Create variable information var_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary[,1:25]),   description = bfi.dictionary$Item[1:25] )  # Interpret directly from model object results <- interpret(fa_result,                      variable_info = var_info,                      llm_provider = "openai",                      llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini")

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: control custom loadings matrices:
code: # Extract loadings manually loadings <- fa_result$loadings  results <- interpret_fa(   loadings = loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "llama3.1:8b" )

title: LLM-powered interpretation of factor and cluster analyses
text: Use persistent chat sessions save tokens analyzing multiple datasets:
code: # Create reusable chat session chat <- chat_fa("anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001")  # Run multiple interpretations result1 <- interpret_fa(loadings1, var_info1, chat_session = chat) result2 <- interpret_fa(loadings2, var_info2, chat_session = chat) result3 <- interpret_fa(loadings3, var_info3, chat_session = chat)  # Check token usage print(chat)

what: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
text: Creates persistent chat session factor analysis interpretation can reused across multiple analyses avoid repeating system prompt reduce token costs.

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
code: chat_fa(provider, model = NULL, params = NULL, echo = "none")

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
text: provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama") model Character. Model name (e.g., "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") params List. ellmer parameters (temperature, etc.). Default uses ellmer::params() echo Character. Echo level ("none", "output", ""). Default "none"

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
text: chat_fa object containing persistent chat session

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
text: chat_fa object stores: persistent ellmer chat session factor analysis system prompt already loaded Provider model information Token usage tracking (cumulative input/output tokens across interpretations) Session metadata (number interpretations run, creation timestamp) allows efficient reuse across multiple factor analysis interpretations without resending system prompt time. Token Tracking Note: Cumulative token counts may approximate providers (e.g., Ollama) cache system prompts. Input tokens may undercounted due caching, output tokens typically accurate. Use results$run_tokens access per-interpretation token counts.

title: Create Factor Analysis Chat Session — chat_fa
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create a persistent chat session chat <- chat_fa("anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001")  # Use with multiple analyses result1 <- interpret_fa(loadings1, var_info1, chat_session = chat) result2 <- interpret_fa(loadings2, var_info2, chat_session = chat)  # Check token usage print(chat) } # }

title: Create a visual representation of factor loadings — create_factor_plot

New code use generic plot() method: plot(interpretation_results). heatmap visualization: Uses LLM-generated suggested factor names (available) Uses blue-white-red color scale (negative positive loadings) Automatically handles suppressed small loadings (empty strings) Rotates factor names better readability Scales variable names appropriately Highlights loadings cutoff black outline

title: Export Factor Analysis Interpretation Report — export_interpretation
text: interpretation_results Results interpret_fa() function - list containing factor analysis interpretation results 'report' element format Character. Export format: "txt" plain text "md" markdown (default = "txt") file Character. File path without extension. appropriate extension (.txt .md) added automatically missing. Can include directory path. Default "fa_interpretation" silent Logical. TRUE, suppresses success message (default = FALSE)

title: Export Factor Analysis Interpretation Report — export_interpretation
text: Invisible TRUE success

title: Export Factor Analysis Interpretation Report — export_interpretation
text: Supported Export Formats: "txt": Exports report plain text format. report interpretation_results generated output_format = "text", exported -. Otherwise, markdown formatting may present. "md": Exports report markdown format. report interpretation_results generated output_format = "markdown", exported proper markdown formatting. Otherwise, export text version. File Extension Handling: function intelligently handles file extensions: provide file = "my_report", becomes "my_report.txt" "my_report.md" provide file = "my_report.txt", stays "my_report.txt" format="txt" Directory paths preserved: "output/report" → "output/report.txt"

title: Export Factor Analysis Interpretation Report — export_interpretation
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get interpretation results in text format results_txt <- interpret_fa(loadings, variable_info,                            output_format = "text",                            silent = TRUE)  # Export as plain text export_interpretation(results_txt, "txt", "my_analysis") # Creates: my_analysis.txt  # Get interpretation results in markdown format results_md <- interpret_fa(loadings, variable_info,                           output_format = "markdown",                           silent = TRUE)  # Export as markdown export_interpretation(results_md, "md", "my_analysis") # Creates: my_analysis.md  # Extension auto-completion works export_interpretation(results_txt, "txt", "my_analysis.txt") # Creates: my_analysis.txt (not my_analysis.txt.txt)  # Export to specific directory export_interpretation(results_md, "md", "output/my_analysis") # Creates: output/my_analysis.md } # }

title: Find Cross-Loading Variables — find_cross_loadings
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Assuming you have factor loadings loadings_df <- data.frame(   variable = c("var1", "var2", "var3"),   Factor1 = c(0.8, 0.4, 0.1),   Factor2 = c(0.2, 0.7, 0.9) )  # Find variables loading on multiple factors (auto-detect factor columns) cross_vars <- find_cross_loadings(loadings_df, cutoff = 0.3)  # Or specify factor columns explicitly cross_vars <- find_cross_loadings(loadings_df, c("Factor1", "Factor2"), cutoff = 0.3) print(cross_vars) } # }

title: Interpret Factor Analysis Results Using S3 Methods — interpret
text: fa_interpretation object (see interpret_fa details)

title: Interpret Factor Analysis Results Using S3 Methods — interpret
text: generic function provides unified interface interpreting factor analysis results multiple R packages. Package-specific methods automatically extract loadings factor correlations fitted model objects. Supported Model Types: psych::fa() - Exploratory factor analysis (class: psych.fa) psych::principal() - Principal components analysis (class: psych.principal) lavaan::cfa(), lavaan::sem(), lavaan::lavaan() - CFA/SEM (class: lavaan) lavaan::efa() output="efa" - EFA (class: efaList) mirt::mirt() - Multidimensional IRT (class: SingleGroupClass) Methods automatically detect extract: Factor loadings matrix (variables × factors) Factor correlations oblique rotations (available)

title: Interpret Factor Analysis Results Using S3 Methods — interpret
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Set up API credentials Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-api-key-here")  # Example with psych package library(psych) fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")  var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c("Miles per gallon", "Number of cylinders",                   "Displacement", "Horsepower") )  # Interpret using S3 method result <- interpret(fa_model, variable_info = var_info,                     llm_provider = "openai",                     llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini")  # Example with lavaan package library(lavaan) model <- 'visual  =~ x1 + x2 + x3           textual =~ x4 + x5 + x6           speed   =~ x7 + x8 + x9' fit <- cfa(model, data = HolzingerSwineford1939)  var_info_lavaan <- data.frame(   variable = paste0("x", 1:9),   description = paste("Indicator", 1:9) )  result <- interpret(fit, variable_info = var_info_lavaan,                     llm_provider = "anthropic",                     llm_model = "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") } # }

what: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: function uses Large Language Models (LLMs) automatically interpret FA results analyzing factor loadings variable descriptions. generates suggested factor names, detailed interpretations, identifies cross-loadings. Variance explained automatically calculated loadings (sum squared loadings / number variables).

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
code: interpret_fa(   loadings,   variable_info,   factor_cor_mat = NULL,   chat_session = NULL,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = NULL,   params = NULL,   cutoff = 0.3,   n_emergency = 2,   sort_loadings = TRUE,   additional_info = NULL,   word_limit = 150,   output_format = "text",   heading_level = 1,   suppress_heading = FALSE,   max_line_length = 80,   silent = FALSE,   echo = "none" )

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: loadings dataframe matrix factor loadings (variables x factors) variable_info dataframe least two columns: variable: variable names matching row names loadings description: labels descriptions variables factor_cor_mat Matrix data.frame. Optional factor correlation matrix oblique rotations. factor names row column names matching loadings factor columns. Used inform interpretation factor relationships enhance understanding discriminant validity. Higher correlations suggest related constructs, lower correlations indicate distinct factors. NULL, factors assumed orthogonal (default = NULL) chat_session chat_fa object reusing existing chat sessions. provided, uses existing chat session (avoiding resending system prompt reducing token costs). NULL, creates new chat session. Useful processing multiple analyses efficiently (default = NULL) llm_provider Character. LLM provider use. provider supported ellmer::chat() (e.g., "openai", "anthropic", "ollama", etc.) See ellmer documentation complete list supported providers. llm_model Character. Specific model use (e.g., "gpt-4o-mini", "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022", "gemma2:9b") params Parameters LLM created using ellmer::params() function (e.g., params(temperature = 0.7, seed = 42)). Provides provider-agnostic interface setting model parameters like temperature, seed, max_tokens, etc. NULL, uses provider defaults. See ellmer::params() documentation supported parameters. cutoff Numeric. Minimum loading value consider (default = 0.3) n_emergency Integer. factor loadings cutoff, use top N highest loadings (even cutoff) interpretation (default = 2) sort_loadings Logical. Sort variables loading strength within factors (default = TRUE) additional_info Character. Optional additional context LLM, theoretical background, research area information, domain-specific knowledge inform factor interpretation (default = NULL) word_limit Integer. Maximum number words LLM interpretations (default = 150) output_format Character. Output format report: "text" "markdown" (default = "text") heading_level Integer. Starting heading level markdown output (default = 1). Used output_format = "markdown" suppress_heading Logical. TRUE, suppresses main "Exploratory Factor Analysis Interpretation" heading, allowing better integration existing documents already appropriate headings analysis output (default = FALSE) max_line_length Integer. Maximum line length console output text wrapping (default = 80) silent Logical. TRUE, suppresses printing interpretation report progress bars console (default = FALSE) echo Character. Controls echoed LLM interaction. One "none" (output), "output" (show LLM responses), "" (show prompts responses). Passed directly ellmer chat function debugging transparency (default = "none")

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: fa_interpretation object (S3 class) containing: factor_summaries List detailed analysis factor, including variables, loadings, significance status, variance_explained suggested_names Named list LLM-generated factor names loading_matrix Formatted loading matrix small loadings optionally suppressed report Complete formatted text/markdown report including factor correlations (provided) llm_info List containing provider name model used interpretation chat Complete ellmer chat object full conversation history cost information cross_loadings Data frame variables loading significantly multiple factors no_loadings Data frame variables loadings cutoff threshold elapsed_time Total analysis time difftime object factor_cor_mat Factor correlation matrix (provided) cutoff Numeric cutoff value used determining significant loadings

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: function uses advanced processing minimize LLM API calls costs. Instead individual factor interpretation calls, processes factors simultaneously single comprehensive prompt structured sections optimal LLM comprehension. Key Features: Structured LLM Prompting: Uses organized sections (Factor Naming, Factor Interpretation, Factor Relationships, Output Requirements) consistent, high-quality results Factor Correlation Integration: factor_cor_mat provided, incorporates factor relationships interpretations enhanced discriminant validity assessment Optimized Word Targeting: Targets 80%-100% word limit comprehensive interpretations Emergency Rule: Factors loadings cutoff use top N highest loadings Cross-loading Detection: Identifies variables loading multiple factors Batch Processing: Single API call processes factors simultaneously Technical Details: Variance explained calculated sum squared loadings divided number variables Supports orthogonal (factor_cor_mat = NULL) oblique rotation results Uses compact vector format efficient token usage LLM prompts JSON output parsing fallback extraction methods robustness

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
text: function requires: Internet connectivity LLM API calls Valid API credentials chosen LLM provider (set via environment variables) ellmer package LLM communication

title: Interpret Exploratory Factor Analysis Results — interpret_fa
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Set up API credentials first Sys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "your-api-key-here")  # Assuming you have factor analysis results library(psych) fa_results <- psych::fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2)  # Create variable info dataframe with realistic descriptions var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c(     "Miles per gallon fuel efficiency",     "Number of engine cylinders",     "Engine displacement in cubic inches",     "Engine horsepower output"   ) )  # Basic interpretation with OpenAI interpretation <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini" )  # Using persistent chat session for multiple analyses (efficient) chat <- chat_fa("anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001")  # Multiple analyses with same chat session (saves tokens) interpretation1 <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results1$loadings,   variable_info = var_info1,   chat_session = chat )  interpretation2 <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results2$loadings,   variable_info = var_info2,   chat_session = chat )  # Check total token usage print(chat)  # Advanced usage with factor correlations and custom settings interpretation_advanced <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "llama3.1:8b",   additional_info = "This analysis examines automotive performance characteristics.",   factor_cor_mat = fa_results$cor,  # Factor correlation matrix for oblique rotations   cutoff = 0.4,   word_limit = 120,   params = params(temperature = 0.3, seed = 123),   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 2,   silent = TRUE )  # Usage with factor correlations for oblique rotation fa_oblique <- psych::fa(mtcars[,1:7], nfactors = 3, rotate = "oblimin") interpretation_oblique <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_oblique$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   factor_cor_mat = fa_oblique$Phi,  # Use factor correlation matrix from oblique rotation   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini",   additional_info = "Oblique rotation allowing correlated factors in automotive data" )  # For integration into existing Quarto/R Markdown documents interpretation_embedded <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini",   params = params(temperature = 0.7, seed = 42),   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 3,  # Adjust to fit your document structure   suppress_heading = TRUE  # Skip main heading for better integration )  # For debugging - see what prompts are sent to the LLM interpretation_debug <- interpret_fa(   loadings = fa_results$loadings,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "openai",   llm_model = "gpt-4o-mini",   echo = TRUE  # Display prompts and responses )  # Access results print(interpretation$suggested_names) print(interpretation$report) } # }

title: Print Factor Analysis Interpretation Results — print.fa_interpretation
text: Invisible NULL (prints console)

title: Print Factor Analysis Interpretation Results — print.fa_interpretation
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get interpretation results results <- interpret_fa(loadings, variable_info, silent = TRUE)  # Print with default format (uses stored report) print(results)  # Print with custom line length print(results, max_line_length = 60)  # Convert to markdown format for integration print(results, output_format = "markdown", heading_level = 3)  # Convert back to text format print(results, output_format = "text") } # }
